technique.short-name: Providing alternatives to running headers and footers in PDF documents which have been marked up as artifacts

description.p:
The objective of this technique is to ensure users of screen readers can have access to information which is provided in headers and footers. PDF/UA requires the following:
7.8 Page Headers and footers: Running headers and footers shall be identified as Pagination artifacts and shall be classified as either Header or Footer subtypes as per ISO 32000-1:2008, 14.8.2.2.2, Table 330.

Information that is included in header and footers must be available at least once in the document. This includes information such as classification information on classified documents, copyright information, form numbers, page numbers, or other content that is not located elsewhere in the document.

This content may be placed on the title page or in the prose text of the document. (If for some reason this is not possible, the footer may be marked as non-artifact content on the first and last page of each new header/footer group using a PDF editor such as Acrobat. this way the information is available but does not break up the reading order of content. Authors should be aware that most authoring formats, such as MS Word, mark headers and footers as artifacts by default.)

For page numbers, the Page Labels feature should be used to add Page numbering including section information to identify pages and sections to assistive technology. The page label feature allows flexibility for different number schemes such as Roman numbers and custom label prefixes. Akternatively page numbers may be synced up with the page view

item.p: Current chapter and/or section in the document
Page numbers with location information such as, "Page 3-4" or "Page 9 of 15."

description.p: In the visual presentation, it is a good idea to use headers and footers. This consistency helps users with cognitive limitations, screen-reader users and low-vision magnifier users, and users with intellectual disabilities understand content more readily.

The easiest way to provide page headers and footers is in the authoring tool for the document. Authoring tools typically provide features for creating header and footer text and information (such as page numbers). However, if after converting your document to PDF, you need to add or modify page headers and footers, authoring or repair tools like Adobe Acrobat Pro's Header & Footer tools can be used. In all cases, the tools generate page headers and footers in consistent and predictable layout, format, and text.

eg-group.head: Marking a running header or footer as a pagination artifact in a PDF document using an /Artifact tag or property list

description.p: The PDF specification allows running headers and footers to be marked as "pagination artifacts" as defined in section 14.8.2.2 "Real Content and Artifacts," of PDF 1.7 (ISO 32000-1).
An artifact is explicitly distinguished from real content by enclosing it in a marked-content sequence with the /Artifact tag.
or

The first is used to identify a generic artifact; the second is used for artifacts that have an associated property list. Note: to aid in text reflow, artifacts should be defined with property lists whenever possible. Artifacts lacking a specified bounding box are likely to be discarded during reflow.
Property list entries for artifacts include Type, BBox, Attached, and Subtype.

item.p: Section 14.8.2.2 (Real Content and Artifacts) in PDF 1.7 (ISO 32000-1)
Check that running headers and/or footers are provided and contain information to help users locate themselves within the document (such as page numbers or chapter numbers).
If section headers are used in the running header or footer, check that the section header and the running header or footer are consistent.
